author: nothappygooutside
comment: who is your lecturer? i'm a tp law student here and very honestly a lot of the subjects are self-learnt...

author: nothappygooutside
comment: anyways, here's how i usually structure my answers: -direct answer to the question (one sentence). -cite your statutes/case laws -apply the relevant part of the statute/legal principle to the hypothetical situation business law is generally easy if you don't pay attention to the lecturers - sounds weird but all my peers who have taken business law simply cannot learn from the lecturers because they love going off tangent. google can actually be your best friend and if you want general guides on common law principles, you can read up about it on [singapore law watch.](https://www.singaporelawwatch.sg/About-Singapore-Law/Commercial-Law) singapore law watch saved my life ngl.
analysis:

```json
{
  "sentiment": "negative",
  "topics": ["academic", "lecturers"],
  "complaints": ["Lecturers go off tangent and are difficult to learn from.", "Business law lecturers are ineffective."],
  "suggestions": []
}
```

author: nothappygooutside
comment: print your notes and relevant statutes. you can also print resources found on Lexis Advance (they dont teach u this in business law this is a TP law hack). dont bother printing case laws youre just wasting paper. you dont need to recite the whole facts of the case which is what most people do. just state the legal principle. i PMed OP with additional resources they can bring to the exam, if you need any guides u can PM me

```json

  "sentiment": "positive",
  "topics": ["academic", "business law"],
  "complaints": [],
  "suggestions": ["print notes and relevant statutes", "print resources from Lexis Advance", "don't print case laws", "state legal principle instead of reciting case facts", "PM OP for additional resources and guides"]
}
```
